Award.AwardTitle: SBE: Medium: Towards Personalized Privacy Assistants

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Whether it is on their smartphones, in their browsers or on social networks, people are confronted with an increasingly unmanageable number of privacy settings. What is needed is a new, more scalable paradigm that empowers them to regain control over the collection and use of their data. This is particularly the case for mobile apps people download on their smartphones. These apps have been shown to collect and share a wide variety of sensitive data, with users unable to keep up. If all users felt the same way about the data collection and sharing practices of mobile apps, it would easy to have the apps pre-configured to only allow for those practices with which they are comfortable. Unfortunately, prior research has shown that this is not the case. This project is studying novel technology intended to significantly simplify the process of configuring privacy settings such as those associated with mobile apps. With close to 200 million US smartphone users, each with an average of nearly 50 mobile apps on their devices, this project could have a significant impact on the privacy of everyday Americans.

Specifically, this research harnesses recent advances in privacy preference modeling, machine learning and dialogue technologies to develop personalized privacy assistants capable of learning people's privacy preferences and of semi-automatically configuring many privacy settings on their behalf. The researchers are evaluating different configurations of personalized privacy assistants, focusing in particular on human subject experiments intended to evaluate their impact on privacy decision making and user behavior. Configurations being evaluated differ in the style and frequency of dialogues with users, the way in which machine learning is used to drive these dialogues and the level of automation in configuring privacy settings. Human subject experiments look at factors that include the impact of different configurations of the technologies on the level of comfort users have with their privacy settings, their overall awareness and sense of control, and both short-term and long-term behavioral effects. Other important factors include user burden, frequency of interruptions and overall user satisfaction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Whether it is on their smartphones, in their browsers or on social networks, people are confronted to an increasingly unmanageable number of privacy settings. These privacy settings are in part the result of the increasingly diverse ways in which personal data is collected and used and also reflect new regulatory requirements which require technology providers to give users some control over the collection and use of their data. If everyone felt the same way about the collection and use of their data, privacy settings would not be required: technologies could simply be configured to be compatible with people?s collective privacy preferences. Research shows however that this is not the case, with different people often expressing different preferences.

What is needed is a new, more scalable paradigm that empowers people to make effective use of available privacy settings and regain control over the collection and use of their data. This project focused on the development and validation of privacy assistant technologies designed to harness the power of machine learning technologies to assist users with the management of their privacy ? from selectively notifying them about data practices they would want to be informed about to suggesting ways to control available privacy settings. Specifically, this project contributed significant advances in the development, piloting and evaluation of privacy assistant technologies designed to help people manage their privacy on smartphones and across Internet of Things scenarios. Significant contributions included the development of methodologies and techniques to model people?s privacy preferences and expectations, including the development and validation of predictive models designed to reduce user burden when it comes to helping users manage a large number of privacy decisions.

Significant contributions made by this project included the development and piloting in the wild of a novel privacy assistant designed to help smartphone users manage their mobile app privacy settings. Evaluation of this privacy assistant showed that it was able to predict many of a user?s mobile app permissions and that such functionality could be successfully deployed in the form of functionality that recommends permission settings to users ? rather than automatically making decisions on behalf of users. A version of this mobile app permission manager was successfully released on the Google Play Store. Another significant contribution was the development of privacy preference and expectation models for Internet of Things usage scenarios. This research involved an extensive in-situ study of people?s privacy preferences and expectations in the context of video-analytics deployment scenarios. The study showed that people?s privacy preferences and expectations are often both complex and diverse, yet lend themselves to the development of predictive models, which can be used to assist users manage their privacy choices.

This project also contributed to the development and successful launch of a privacy infrastructure for the Internet of Things. The infrastructure consists of (1) a portal, which people can use to describe and publicize the presence of IoT resources, including their data practices, and of (2) a mobile app privacy assistant which people can use to discover IoT data collection processes around them and access any privacy choices made available by these processes (e.g., opt-in, opt-out). As of late 2020, the infrastructure, which was released earlier in the year, publicizes the presence of nearly 200,000 IoT resource descriptions.

Beyond advances in modeling people?s privacy preferences and expectations and exploring the adoption of different configuration of these technologies, this project helped inform public policy discussions in mobile and IoT privacy, informed technical advances and practices in industry, and also contributed to the training of a number of undergraduate and graduate students.
